div.note: Like a pack of bloodhounds that, having chased a hare in vain, return to their master, humiliated, heads hanging and tails between their legs, the bravi returned to Don Rodrigo’s palace on that night of tricks and treachery.
He was pacing back and forth, in the dark, in a large empty room on the top floor that overlooked the terrace.

Every now and then he would stop, listen, and look between the slats of the worm-eaten shutters. He was filled with impatience and measurable apprehension, not only because of his uncertainty over the outcome but also because of the possible consequences, since this was the biggest and riskiest thing the brave and valiant man had ever attempted.
He kept reassuring himself, however, with thoughts of the precautions he had taken to destroy the evidence if not the suspicions. “Suspicions?” he thought. “I scoff at them.
I’d like to meet the lovesick fool who’d dare to come up here to see whether I’ve got the girl.
Let the lowlife come. He’ll get the welcome he deserves!
Let the friar come.
And the old woman?
Off to Bergamo with her.
The law?
What law!
The Mayor is neither a child nor a fool.
And in Milan?
Who’d want to take them in there? Who’d pay them any mind?
Who even knows them?
They’re lost souls. They don’t even have a master: They belong to no one.
Come now, there’s nothing to be afraid of.
I can’t wait to see the look on Attilio’s face tomorrow morning!
He’ll see if I’m all talk and no action.
And then…if there were any problems, such as, I don’t know, some enemy who wants to take this opportunity…Attilio will have some words of advice, too. After all, our family honor is at stake.”

But the thought on which he dwelled the most, because it both quieted his doubts and fed his obsession, was the thought of the cajoling, the promises he would use to soothe Lucia. “She’ll be so scared to find herself here all alone, surrounded by those ugly mugs—the most human face here is mine, by God—that she’ll have to run to me, to beg. And she will beg.”
While making these calculations, he hears clattering, goes to the window, opens it a crack, and sticks his head out. It’s them. “And the sedan chair?
Damn it, where’s the sedan chair?
Three, five, eight…everyone’s here. Griso, too. But no sedan chair. Damn! Griso’s got some explaining to do!”

Once they were inside, Griso set his walking stick, old hat, and cloak in the corner of a ground-floor room and, as required by his job—which no one envied in that moment—he went upstairs to do some explaining to Don Rodrigo, who was waiting at the top.
Seeing Griso appear with the inept, sheepish look of a thwarted criminal, “Well?” he said, or rather shouted, “Mr. Braggart, Mr. Capitano, Mr. Leaveituptome?”
“It ain’t easy,” answered Griso, one foot still on the first step, “it ain’t easy getting reprimanded after trying your loyal best to do your duty and risking your neck while you’re at it.”
“What happened?

Come on, out with it,” said Don Rodrigo as he headed toward his chambers. Griso followed him and immediately delivered his report of what he had arranged, done, seen and not seen, heard, feared, and fixed. And he did it with the order and confusion, doubtfulness and dismay, that also reigned over his thoughts.
“You did the right thing,” said Don Rodrigo, “you did what you could. But…what if I’ve got a spy under my roof!
If I come to find out I do, and we discover who he is, I’ll take care of him. I can tell you, Griso, I’ll make him pay.”
“The same suspicion crossed my mind,” said Griso. “If it’s true, and if we do find a rat like that, then hand him over to me, master.
He got his laughs putting me through a night like that! I’d like the chance to pay him back.
But a few things make me think some other plot was underway, I’m not sure exactly what right now.
Tomorrow, my lord, tomorrow it’ll all be clear.”
“Tell me that at least no one recognized you.”
Griso answered that he hoped not. Their conversation ended with three orders from Don Rodrigo for the next day, orders that Griso could have easily given himself.

Two men were to be sent early in the morning to deliver a warning to the Consul, which they did, as we have seen; two others were to guard the abandoned house, keep away any idler that might happen to come by, and hide the sedan chair until the next night, when they could bring it back, since for the time being it was best to avoid suspicious movements. And finally, Griso himself was to go, along with a couple of his most calm and levelheaded men, to mingle with the people and try to dig up information about the havoc of that night.

After giving these orders, Don Rodrigo went to bed and gave Griso his leave, too, saying good night with heaps of praise that clearly expressed his wish to compensate for the insults with which he had greeted him earlier.
Time to sleep, poor Griso. I’m sure you need it.
Poor Griso!

Busy all day, busy half the night, not to mention the danger of falling into the villagers’ grips or ending up with a bounty on your head per rapto di donna honesta, in addition to the ones you already have. And then to be welcomed back like that! No good deed goes unpunished.
But, in this instance, you could see that while justice may sometimes lag at the beginning, it does eventually arrive, even in this world.
Go to sleep now. Because one day soon, you might be summoned to tackle another, more formidable task.
The next morning, Griso was already out and about when Don Rodrigo rose.
The nobleman immediately went looking for Count Attilio who, upon his appearance, made a taunting face and gesture, saying, “It’s the Feast of Saint Martin! Time to pay up!”
“I don’t know what to say,” replied Don Rodrigo, coming up to him. “I’ll pay the bet, but that’s not what burns me.
I didn’t say anything to you because, I admit, I thought I might surprise you this morning.
Well…enough. Now I’ll tell you everything.”
“It was that monk sticking his nose into our business,” offered his cousin, after he’d heard the whole story, with greater seriousness than you might have expected from such an eccentric figure.
“That monk,” he continued, “with his pussy-cat manners and foolish ideas, he’s nothing but a smart aleck and a busybody.
And you didn’t trust me. You never told me what he came here to cook up the other day.”
Don Rodrigo described their conversation.
“And you put up with it, letting him leave the same way that he came?” exclaimed Count Attilio.
“What? Did you want me to incur the wrath of all the Capuchins in Italy?”

“In a moment like that,” said Count Attilio, “I don’t know whether I would’ve remembered that there were any other Capuchins in the world besides that insolent rascal. But come now, even within the rules of prudence, is there no way to get the better of a Capuchin?
You have to know when to be especially kind to the whole body in order to attack a single member with impunity. Enough.
He escaped the punishment he had coming to him. But I’ll take him under my protection. I want the satisfaction of teaching him how to speak to people of our class.”
“You’ll only make things worse.”
“Trust me, for once, and I’ll be both relative and friend to you.”
“What do you have in mind?”
“I’m not sure yet, but I’ll definitely give that friar what he deserves.
Let me think about it and…wait, there’s my uncle, the Count, on the Secret Council! He can handle him for me.
My dear Count Uncle!
I love getting him to do my dirty work, a bigwig like him!
I’ll be in Milan the day after tomorrow, and one way or other, the friar will get what he deserves.”
In the meantime, breakfast had arrived, but it did not interrupt the discussion of this important matter.

Count Attilio spoke freely and, although he performed the role demanded by his friendship with his cousin and by the honor of their shared name—according to his own notions of friendship and honor—he couldn’t help but laugh to himself at his cousin’s glorious fiasco.

But Don Rodrigo, whose name was at stake, was roiled by deeper passions and distracted by more vexing thoughts. He thought he could pull off the big coup in silence and had failed to do so clamorously.
“Can you imagine the lies that those lowlifes will spread everywhere?” he said.
“What do I care?
As for the law? I laugh at it. They’ve got no proof. Even if they did, I’d still laugh. For good measure, this morning I warned the Consul not to report what happened.
Nothing would come of it. But rumors annoy me when they go on for too long.
It’s bad enough that I was fooled so brutally.”
“You did the right thing,” replied Count Attilio.

“That mayor of yours—that big stubborn, stupid, pain in the neck of a mayor—is still an honest man, a man who knows his duty. And when you’re dealing with people like that, you have to be careful not to create trouble for them.
If some rascal of a consul makes a report, the Mayor, with all the good intentions in the world, still has to—”
“You’re one to talk!” Don Rodrigo broke in, irritated. “Always contradicting him about everything, shouting at him, and even ridiculing him if you feel like it. Spoiling my best-laid plans!
For crying out loud, how can a mayor be a stubborn mule and an honest man at the same time?”
“You know, dear Cousin,” said Count Attilio, looking at him with surprise, “I’m starting to think you’re a little afraid.
You’re even taking the Mayor seriously!”
“Oh, come now, weren’t you the one who said we have to keep him happy?”
“I did. And when it comes to serious business, I’ll show you I’m no boy.
You know how far I’ll go for you?
I’m the type of man who’ll call on the Mayor myself.
Will he appreciate the honor?
And I’m the type of man who’ll let him talk for half an hour about the Count-Duke, about our Spanish castellan, ready to agree with everything he says, even when he’s talking complete rubbish.
Then I’ll slip in a word or two about the Count Uncle, on the Secret Council, and you know how those words will sound to the Mayor’s ears!
When all is said and done, he needs our protection more than you need his indulgence.
I’ll do a good deed and go there, and leave him better disposed to you than ever.”
After these words and more of the same, Count Attilio left to go hunting. Don Rodrigo stayed behind, anxiously awaiting the return of Griso, who finally arrived, at suppertime, to deliver his report.

The havoc of that night had created such an uproar, and the disappearance of three people from a small village was such an event, that the searches—driven by a sense of both urgency and curiosity—were many, heated, and insistent. On the other hand, too many people had a piece of the puzzle for everyone to agree to keep quiet.

Perpetua couldn’t appear on her doorstop without being assailed by someone or other, to get her to say who had given her master such a fright. Thinking back on the circumstances, she was finally able to figure out that she had been duped by Agnese, which made her so mad that she simply had to let off some steam.

Not that she went around complaining to the world of how she had been duped. On that she didn’t breathe a word. But she couldn’t keep quiet about the trick played on her poor master, especially one hatched and carried out by that upright young man, that saintly widow, and that goody two-shoes.

Don Abbondio could order her sternly or beg her politely to be quiet, and she could repeat that there was no need to tell her something so plain and clear. But the secret locked in the poor woman’s heart was so big that, like a loosely hooped old barrel filled with a gurgling, bubbling, fermenting young wine, if the tap didn’t blow off, every stave was bound to creak and leak and drip so much that, soon enough, you’d be able to name the wine inside.

Gervaso, who could scarcely believe that for once he was better informed than everyone else, thought it glorious to have suffered such a scare, and felt as if having had a hand in something that reeked of criminality made him a man like the others, was dying to boast about it.
And although Tonio, who was worried about inquiries and possible trials and explanations, ordered him at fist-point to keep his mouth shut, there was still no way to stifle every word from his mouth.

For that matter, Tonio himself, after being out that night at such an unusual hour, coming home with such an unusual gait and demeanor, and with an agitation that made him inclined to honesty, could not hide the fact from his wife, who was in turn no mute.

The one who spoke the least was Menico, because as soon as he told his parents the story and the reasons for his expedition, they were so terrified that their son had helped foil a plot by Don Rodrigo that they barely let him finish his story.

They immediately issued him the sternest and most threatening order to not even hint at what had happened to anyone. The next morning, still not feeling safe, they decided to keep him locked up at home for the day, and then for a few days more.

To no avail! Because while his parents were chatting with fellow villagers a little later, without intending to boast, they themselves spilled the hitherto mysterious details of our friends’ escape, as well as the how, the why, and the where, adding, as if it were common knowledge, that the three had found sanctuary in Pescarenico.
And so this fact, too, made its way into the village gossip.

With all these scraps of news pieced and sewn together and the embellishments that inevitably get added on in the process, a story emerged with enough certainty and clarity to satisfy even the most skeptical minds.
But the invasion of the bravi—an incident too serious and too raucous to ignore—complicated the whole affair.
Everyone agreed that Don Rodrigo was behind it. The rest was all mystery and opposing conjectures.
There was much talk of the two bravi who had been seen on the street toward nightfall, and of the one standing at the tavern door. But did this simple fact illuminate anything?

The tavern-keeper was questioned to find out who had been at his establishment the night before. But, if he was to be believed, he did not even remember whether he had seen people that night, and was careful to say that a tavern is like a seaport, with people coming in and out.

What most confounded people and upset their conjectures was Stefano’s and Carlandrea’s sighting of a pilgrim, who the criminals wanted to murder, and who had either gone with or been kidnapped by them.
What was he doing there?

Was he a soul from Purgatory that had appeared to help the women? The condemned soul of a villain posing as a pilgrim who came by night to be united with those who were committing the same crimes that he had in his lifetime? Or was he a real flesh-and-blood pilgrim that they wanted to kill, for fear that he would shout and wake up the village? Or (can you believe what people will think!) was he actually one of the crooks, disguised as a pilgrim? He was this, he was that, he was so many things that all of Griso’s wisdom and experience would not have sufficed to discover who he was, if he had been forced to reconstruct the story on the basis of the rumors in town.

As the reader knows, however, what was most confusing for others was the very thing that was clearest to him. Using it as the key to interpret the bits and pieces of information he had gathered himself, or through his underlings, he was able to compose a fairly detailed report for Don Rodrigo.

Griso informed his master of the trick the poor couple had attempted—explaining the empty house and the ringing of the church bell—which eliminated any suspicions of a traitor in their midst and confirmed what the two upstanding gentlemen had said.

He informed him of the escape, which was also easy to explain: the couple’s fear at getting caught in the wrong, unless they had received some warning of the invasion when the village was in an uproar.
In conclusion, he said that they had found sanctuary in Pescarenico. And that’s as far as his knowledge went.
Don Rodrigo was pleased to know for certain that no one had betrayed him, and that nothing could be traced to him, but his pleasure was fleeting and brief.
“They fled together!” he cried. “Together!
And that rascal of a monk!”
The name stuck in his throat and rattled between his teeth, which were biting his finger. His expression was as brutal as his passion.
“That friar will pay for this!
Griso! Doesn’t he know who I am?…I want to know, I want to find…I want to know where they are tonight!
I won’t rest!
To Pescarenico, immediately! To know! To see!
To find!…Here’s four scudi now, and my protection forever.
I have to know by tonight.
And that rascal, that friar…”
Once more unto the breach for Griso. That same night, he was able to bring his worthy master the coveted news. Let me tell you how he managed.
One of the greatest consolations in life is friendship. And one of the consolations of friendship is having someone in whom to confide a secret.
But friends don’t come in pairs, like married couples. Each of us generally has more than one, which forms a chain whose end no one can trace.
So when a friend secures the consolation of trusting a secret to another friend, he makes that friend want to seek the same consolation himself.
He begs him not to tell a soul, it’s true, and if this condition were to be strictly observed, it would immediately cut off the flow of consolation.
According to general practice, however, the secret should not be confided, except to another equally trusted friend and under the same conditions.
So from trusted friend to trusted friend, the secret travels the length of that immense chain until it reaches the ear of the very person or persons whom the first person did not want to hear it.
This would normally take a very long time, if everyone had only two friends: the one who tells and the one who repeats the thing that should not be told.
But there are privileged men who have hundreds of friends, and when the secret reaches one of them, the rounds become so quick and so many that it is no longer possible to keep track of it.

Our author could not ascertain how many mouths had traded the secret that Griso had been ordered to dig up. The fact of the matter is that at around four-thirty in the afternoon, as he was returning to Pescarenico in his cart, the good man who had escorted the women to Monza ran into a trusted friend to whom he told, in the utmost confidence, the good deed he had done and all the rest. And the fact of the matter is that two hours later, Griso was able to rush back to the palace and report to Don Rodrigo that Lucia and her mother had taken shelter at a convent in Monza, and that Renzo had continued on to Milan.
Don Rodrigo felt a malicious joy at their separation, and a rekindling of the malicious hope that he would achieve his goal.
He was awake most of the night plotting how he could succeed, and woke up early with two plans: one polished, the other still rough.
The first was to send Griso to Monza at once, for more concrete news about Lucia, and to find out whether anything could be attempted.
So he immediately summoned his faithful servant, placed four scudi in his palm, praised again the skill by which he had earned his reward, and gave him the premeditated order.
“My lord,” replied Griso, hemming and hawing.
“What? Wasn’t I clear?”
“If you could send someone else…”
“What?”
“Your Lordship, I am ready to risk my neck for my master. It is my duty. But I also know that you do not want to unduly risk the lives of your subjects.”
“And?”
“Your Lordship knows of the bounty on my head, and…Here I am under your protection.
We’re a brigade. The Mayor is a friend of the family. The police respect me, and I respect them…it does me no honor, but anything for the sake of a peaceful life…I treat them like friends.
In Milan your livery is known. But in Monza…I’m the one that’s known.
And does your Lordship realize that anyone who managed to hand me over to the law, or present my head, would strike it rich?
And I’m not just saying this.
One hundred scudi, dead or alive, and the right to free two bandits!”

“What the devil!” cried Don Rodrigo. “Now you’re acting like a straw dog. You’re only brave enough to nip at the legs of passersby, always turning your head to make sure you’re backed up by the other dogs in the house, and afraid to wander too far from the door!”
“I believe, master, that I’ve proved…”
“So?”
“So,” Griso continued frankly, his back against the wall, “let’s pretend I didn’t say anything: Brave as a lion, swift as a hare, and I’m ready to go.”
“I didn’t say you should go alone.
Take two of your best men along with you…Scarface and Straight Shooter. Pull yourself together and act like the Griso I know.
What the hell?
Three men like you, minding their own business—who do you think would stop them at the gates?
The Monza police would have to be tired of living if they were ready to lay everything on the line for one hundred scudi.
And then, and then, I don’t think I’m so unknown in those parts that the quality of my servant counts for nothing.”
Having thus shamed Griso, he gave him more complete and detailed instructions.

Griso took his two partners and left, putting on a happy and brazen face, while in his heart he cursed Monza and bounties on heads and women and the whims of masters. He walked like a famished wolf, its stomach hollow, its ribs sticking out, coming down from mountains where there is nothing but snow, advancing warily across the plain, and stopping every so often, one paw raised, and wagging its mangy tail:
“Lifting its muzzle to sniff the treacherous air.”
Whenever it catches a scent of man or steel, it pricks its sharp ears and surveys the land with two bloodshot eyes, gleaming with lust for the prey and terror of the hunt.

(For anyone interested in knowing its origin, by the way, that lovely verse is taken from a tangled tale, unpublished, of crusades and Lombards, which will soon no longer be unpublished and is bound to make quite an impression. I have used it since it fits my purpose, and I mention where I found it so as not to take credit for another’s work. I wouldn’t want anyone to think this is my sly way of indicating that the author of that tale and I are like brothers, and that I riffle through his manuscripts at my leisure.)

The other thing nagging at Don Rodrigo was how to keep Renzo from returning to Lucia and ever setting foot in Pescarenico again. To this end, he plotted to spread rumors of threats and hidden dangers such that, when Renzo came to hear of them through a friend, as is usually the case, he would be discouraged from ever returning to these parts.
But the safest thing, he thought, would be if he could get him officially banished from the state. To succeed in this, he saw that he would need the courts, rather than simply brute force.

One way would be to embellish the attempt made at the priest’s house and depict it as an act of aggression and sedition, and through the intercession of Professor Argle-Bargle, suggest to the Mayor that perhaps a warrant should be issued for Renzo’s arrest.

He realized, however, that he’d better not stir up that hornet’s nest. Before wracking his brains any further, he decided to confide in Argle-Bargle just enough to make him understand his wishes. “There are so many decrees!” he thought. “And the lawyer is no fool. I’m sure he can find one that suits this case, some hair to split for that redneck, or his name’s not Argle-Bargle!” But (as sometimes happens in this world) while he was thinking that the lawyer was the best man to help him in this matter, another man, a man whom no one would have imagined—Renzo himself, to be precise—was working wholeheartedly to serve the nobleman’s purposes more surely and swiftly than anything the lawyer could have dreamed up.

I myself have often observed a dear impish little boy, a little too impish, to be honest, but showing signs of wanting to become a fine man. I have often observed him, as I was saying, toward evening, attempting to round up his herd of guinea pigs, which he allows to run free in the yard all day.

He tries to get them to go into their pen together, but it’s always in vain. One heads right, and while the little shepherd runs to corral him back, one, two, or three others escape to the left, and in every direction.
Eventually, after losing his patience, he adapts to their game, and pushes the ones closest to the gate inside, and then collects the others, in ones, twos, or threes, as best he can.
We should play a similar game with our characters: Having found shelter for Lucia, we raced to Don Rodrigo; and now we have to abandon him to chase after Renzo, of whom we had lost sight.

— After the painful separation that I have described, you can easily imagine Renzo’s state of mind as he walked from Monza to Milan: leaving his home, abandoning his trade, and worst of all, being separated from Lucia, and finding himself on a road without knowing where he would end up. All because of that scoundrel!

When he dwelled on one or the other of these matters, he was filled with rage and the desire for revenge. But then he would remember the prayer that he, too, had said with the good friar in the church of Pescarenico. And he would vow to mend his ways. Then his anger would start to rise again, but every time he saw a roadside shrine, he would remove his hat and stop for a moment to pray. Indeed on that journey in his heart he must have killed Don Rodrigo and resuscitated him at least twenty times.

Back then the road was surrounded by two tall muddy, rocky banks, and furrowed by deep grooves that turned into gutters after a rainstorm. In deeper parts it became so flooded that you could cross them in a boat.
At those spots, a short steep pathway up some steps on the embankment indicated that other travelers had cut through the fields.

Climbing up one of those paths to higher ground, Renzo saw the great monument of the Milan cathedral, the Duomo, rising from across the plain, as if it stood not in the middle of a city but of a desert. And he stopped for a moment, forgetting all his troubles to contemplate from afar that eighth wonder of the world, which he had heard so much about ever since childhood.

After a while, he turned around, and his eyes were drawn to the jagged crest of mountains on the horizon: standing out distinct from and high above the others was his Resegone. He felt his blood stirring, and he stood there gazing sadly in that direction, and then sadly turned around and continued on his way.

Little by little he began to make out campanili and towers and domes and roofs. Then he returned to the road and walked for a while longer. When he realized he was close to the city, he approached a passerby and, bowing with all the courtesy he knew, asked, “Beg your pardon, sir?”
“How might I help you, young man?”
“Could you tell me the shortest way to get to the Capuchin monastery, where Padre Bonaventura is?”

The man that Renzo addressed was a well-to-do resident of the region who had been to Milan on business that day, and was on his way back without having accomplished what he had set out to do. He was in a hurry and couldn’t wait to get home, and would gladly have avoided being stopped.

Nevertheless, without showing any sign of impatience, he responded very courteously: “My dear son, there is more than one monastery. You’ll have to tell me more clearly the name of the one you’re looking for.”

Renzo removed Fra Cristoforo’s letter from under his shirt and showed it to the gentleman. When the man saw the words, Porta Orientale, he handed it back to Renzo saying, “You are in luck, young man. The monastery you are looking for is not far from here.

Take this path on the left. It’s a shortcut. In a few minutes you’ll come to the corner of a long, low building. That’s the lazaretto. Go around the ditch that surrounds it and you’ll be at Porta Orientale.
Pass through and in a couple hundred yards you’ll see a small piazza with big elm trees. The monastery is right there. You can’t miss it.
Godspeed, young man.”
And punctuating his last words with a gracious hand gesture, he continued on his way.

Renzo was amazed and enlighted by the courtesy of the citizens to people from the country. He didn’t realize that it was no ordinary day, for it was a day when the aristocrats yielded to the common folk.
He followed the path that had been pointed out to him and arrived at Porta Orientale.
At the sound of this name, readers should avoid letting their imaginations run wild with the way this city gate looks today.
At the time that Renzo entered the city through there, the outer road ran straight only for the length of the lazaretto, after which it became narrow and twisting, passing between two hedges.
The gate itself consisted of two pillars topped by a roof to shield the doors. On one side was a gatehouse for the customs officers.
The ramparts descended in an uneven slope and the ground was rough and littered with rubbish and pottery shards that had been dumped everywhere.
The road that opened before those who entered through Porta Orientale could easily be compared to the entrance to Porta Tosa today.
A ditch ran down the middle of it almost right up to the gate, dividing the road into two winding lanes paved with dust or mud, depending on the season.
At the point where the Borghetto alleyway used to be located and still is today, the ditch disappeared into a sewer.

In that spot there used to be a column with a cross on top known as the San Dionigi Column. To the right and left were gardens bordered by hedges. At intervals there were cottages inhabited, for the most part, by washerwomen.

Renzo went in and passed through the gate. None of the customs officers paid him any mind. He found this strange since, according to the few people from his village who could boast of having been to Milan, he had heard awful stories about country folk being subjected to searches and questions upon arrival.
The road was so deserted that, if he hadn’t heard a buzzing in the distance that indicated great movement, he would have felt as if he were entering a ghost town.

Continuing on, without knowing what to think, he noticed powdery white stripes, like snow, on the ground. But it couldn’t be snow, which doesn’t come down in stripes, nor does it usually appear in that season.
He bent down over one of them, stared at it, touched it, and discovered that it was flour. “What abundance there must be in Milan,” he said to himself, “if they squander God’s grace like this.
And they’d have us believe the famine is everywhere.
So this is how they keep the poor country folk quiet.”

After a few more yards he came to the side of the column and saw something even stranger at its base. On the steps of the pedestal things were scattered here and there that were certainly not cobblestones. If he’d seen them on a baker’s counter, he wouldn’t have hesitated for a second to call them bread loaves.

Renzo did not dare believe his eyes, since this was no place for bread, for goodness’ sake. “Let’s see what’s going on here,” he said to himself. He walked toward the column, stooped down, and picked one up.

It was indeed a round loaf of bread, pure white, of the type that Renzo was used to eating only on feast days. “It really is bread,” he said aloud in amazement. “Is this how they grow it, in a place like this, at a time like this? In a year like this? And they don’t even bother picking it up when it falls?

What is this, the land of plenty?” After ten miles of walking in the fresh morning air, that bread, together with his amazement, reawakened his appetite. “Should I take it?” he asked himself. “Well, they left it here for the dogs to help themselves. No reason a Christian shouldn’t enjoy it.

Anyway, if the owner appears, I’ll pay him for it.” With these thoughts, he pocketed the one in his hand, put a second in his other pocket, and began to eat a third. He continued on his way, more uncertain than ever, and anxious to get to the bottom of this strange story.
As soon as he set out again, he saw people coming toward him from the center of town. He took a close look at the first to appear.
They were a man and a woman, trailed by a boy a few steps behind; all three were bearing a burden superior to their strength; and all three cut a strange figure indeed.

Their clothes, or rather the rags they wore, were covered with flour, as were their faces, which were contorted and flushed. They walked doubled over not only from weight but also apparently from pain, as if they’d been beaten.
The man struggled to balance on his shoulders a big sack of flour riddled with holes that leaked flour with his every stumble and wobble.

The figure of the woman was even more grotesque: an immense belly that she labored to hold between her folded arms, as if it were an old two-handled kettle. Beneath her belly were two legs, staggering along, and naked from the knee down.

Renzo took a closer look and realized that the large belly was the woman’s skirt, which she was holding up by the hem, having filled it with as much flour as could fit, and then some, so that with almost every step another smattering blew away.

With both hands the boy was holding on his head a basket piled high with bread. Since his legs were shorter than his parents’, he lagged a little behind, and every time he quickened his step to reach them, the basket tipped and another loaf of bread would fall out.
“Throw another one away, why don’t you, you good-for-nothing,” the mother snarled at him.
“I’m not throwing them away. They fall by themselves. What am I supposed to do?” the boy replied.

“Lucky for you my hands are busy,” the woman continued, waving her fists, as if she were giving a good shake to the poor lad. And with that gesture she scattered more flour than it would take to bake two of the loaves that the boy had dropped.
“Keep moving,” the man said, “we’ll go back for them later, or someone else will.
We’ve been scraping by for so long. Let’s enjoy this moment of plenty in peace.”
In the meantime other people were arriving through the gates. One of them approached the woman and asked, “Where do you go to get bread?”
“Straight ahead,” she replied. The minute they left she added, grumbling, “These thieving peasants are going to clean out all the bakery shops and all the warehouses, and nothing’ll be left for us.”
“There’s plenty enough to go around, you old nag,” said the husband, “plenty for everyone.”

From this exchange and other things that he saw and heard, it began to dawn on Renzo that the city he had entered was in revolt, and today was a day of victory, each man taking in proportion to his desire or strength, and paying with his fists.
Much as I would like our poor mountain boy to provide a good example for my readers, historical truth obliges me to admit that the first thing he felt was pleasure.
He had so little to celebrate in the ordinary run of things that he was inclined to approve of anything that might change things in any way.

Besides, since he was not a man who rose above his times, he shared the common opinion or conviction that the frequent bread shortages were caused by the hoarders and the bakers. Therefore, he was inclined to approve of any means of wresting from their grasp the food which they, according to that opinion, had cruelly denied to the hungry population.
Still, he decided to stay out of the tumult, and was glad that he was headed to see a Capuchin friar who would find him shelter and act as a father to him.
Bearing this in mind, and gazing all the while at the latest wave of victors laden with spoils, he traveled the short distance remaining to the monastery.

Where a beautiful palace, with a high loggia, stands today, there used to be (until not so many years ago) a small piazza, at the far end of which the church and the monastery of the Capuchin Friars were located, with four large elm trees in front.
And I congratulate, not without envy, those of my readers who never saw things in those conditions. It means that they are very young and that they have not had time for much nonsense.
Renzo went straight to the door, slipped under his shirt the half loaf of bread he had left, took out the letter and readied it in his hand, and rang the bell.
A small grated window opened and the face of the friar who minded the door appeared, asking who he might be.
“A man from the countryside, bringing an urgent letter from Padre Cristoforo to Padre Bonaventura.”
“Give it here,” said the doorkeeper, placing a hand on the grate.
“No, no,” said Renzo, “I am supposed to deliver it to him personally.”
“He’s not at the monastery.”
“If you let me in, I’ll wait for him.”
“Do as I say,” the friar replied, “go and wait in the church, where you can do some good.
As for the monastery, at the moment, you cannot enter.”
With that, he closed the opening back up.
Renzo stood there with the letter in hand.
He took a few steps toward the entrance of the church, following the doorkeeper’s advice. But then, on second thought, he decided to have another look at the turmoil being stirred up by the revolt.

He crossed the square, went to the side of the road, and stopped, his arms folded over his chest. He glanced to the left, toward the center of the city, where the swarm of people was louder and more crowded, drawing him into the vortex.
“Let’s go see,” he said to himself. He took out his half loaf of bread and, munching on it, started off in that direction.
And while he is walking, let me relate as briefly as possible the reasons and the origins of the unrest.
